tn.text: a hollow space under the ground, generally opening into the side of a hill, large enough for people to enter
This is the name of a town near the city of Gath. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
heard that David had gone to hide in the cave

tn.ref: Everyone who was in distress ... everyone who was discontented
tn.text: This is an exaggeration. AT: "Many people who were distressed ... many people who were unhappy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
military officer who leads soldiers
"400" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"Then David went from the cave at Adullam"
This is the name of a city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

David wanted his parents to live with the king of Moab so that King Saul would not be able to harm them. Translators can express his basic meaning by using the ideas of "come to stay with you," "stay with you," or "live here with you," as in the UDB.

tn.ref: go into the land of Judah
tn.text: "go to your home land of Judah"
This is the name of a city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: David had been discovered, along with the men who were with him
tn.text: Saul was most interested in David, so the writer mentions the other men separately. This can be translated in active form. AT: "someone had discovered where David and all the men who were with him were hiding" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is a type of tree. AT: "a large shade tree" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
Ramah is the name of a place in Gibeah. The name means "high place." Possible meanings are 1) it refers here to the place called Ramah, or 2) it refers to any high place. AT: "on a hill" (UDB)

tn.ref: Will the son of Jesse give every one of you fields and vineyards?
tn.text: Saul uses a question to emphasize that David, who is from the tribe of Judah, does not desire to do this for the people of the tribe of Benjamin. AT: "The son of Jesse will not give you fields or vineyards." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Will the son of Jesse give
tn.text: The time when he will give can be made explicit. AT: "When the son of Jesse becomes king, will he give" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"David"

tn.ref: Will he make you all captains ... me?
tn.text: Saul uses a question to emphasize that David, who is from the tribe of Judah, does not desire to do this for the people of the tribe of Benjamin. AT: "He will not make you captains ... against me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Will he make you all captains
tn.text: You may need to make explicit when he will make them captains. AT: "When he becomes king, will he make you all captains" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
military officers who lead soldiers
man's name. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:21:07|21:7]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
place name and man's name. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:21:01|21:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
man's name (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: He prayed to Yahweh that he might help him, and he gave him
tn.text: Ahitub prayed to Yahweh that Yahweh might help David, and Ahitub gave David
"by giving"
"rebel" or "fight"

tn.ref: Who among all your servants is so faithful as David ... house?
tn.text: This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "None of your servants is as faithful as David ... house." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
a person or group of people who protect someone

The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. This can be translated in active form. AT: "whom your family honors" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Is today the first time I have prayed to God to help him?
tn.text: Ahimelech asks himself this question before Saul can ask it, then immediately answers it. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "This is not the first time I have prayed to God to help David." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This idiom means "Absolutely not!" [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Do not let the king impute anything to his servant or to all the house of my father. For your servant knows nothing
tn.text: Ahimelech speaks of himself in the third person as the "servant." Ahimelech also refers to Saul in the third person as "the king." Ahimelech speaks this way to show respect to Saul. AT: "Please, King Saul, do not consider me, your servant, or anyone in the house of my father to be guilty. For I know nothing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
to consider someone guilty

tn.ref: to all the house of my father
tn.text: Here "house" represents "family." AT: "to all my father's family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. AT: "your father's family" or "your father's descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the guard that stood around him
tn.text: "the soldiers standing nearby to protect him"
Here "Turn" means to turn around or turn away from the king. AT: "Go and kill" or "Kill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: their hand also is with David
tn.text: The word "hand" is a metonym for the work done with the hand. AT: "they also help David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: would not put out their hand to kill
tn.text: The word "hand" is a metonym for the work done with the hand. AT: "did not do anything to kill" or "refused to kill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Turn and kill the priests ... turned and attacked the priests
tn.text: Here "Turn" means to turn around or turn away from the king. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:22:16|22:17]]. AT: "Go and kill the priests ... went and attacked" or "Kill the priest ... attacked the priests" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Doeg the Edomite turned and attacked ... he killed ... he attacked ... He killed
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Doeg killed all the priests himself or 2) the word "Doeg" is a synecdoche for Doeg and the men who went with him. AT: "Doeg and his men turned and attacked ... they killed ... they attacked ... They killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
five persons** - "85 people" or "85 priests" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: With the edge of the sword
tn.text: "With a sword" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "attacked" means killed. AT: "he killed many people in the city of Nob" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
man's name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
